required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on November 19, 2021
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Embr Thermal Device for Hot Flash Management in Prostate Cancer
clinical_study.official_title: Feasibility of the Embr Thermal Device for Management of Hot Flashes in Men With Prostate Cancer

brief_summary.textblock: This study is being conducted to evaluate if the Embr thermal device is useful for men who experience bothersome hot flashes as a result of prostate cancer treatment.

detailed_description.textblock: The Embr thermal device is a smart device that is worn on the inside of the wrist. It is about the size of a smart watch. The Embr thermal device produces cooling or warming temperature sensations that make some people feel slightly cooler or warmer. This objective of this study is to evaluate if the Embr thermal device is useful for men who experience bothersome hot flashes as a result of prostate cancer treatment. The study will take place over 4 weeks. The primary outcome is feasibility of the Embr thermal device in men with prostate cancer. Secondary outcomes include preliminary efficacy of the device, which will include the change in hot flash interference sleep measures (sleep impairment and fatigue). This is a remote study--all study assessments will be completed electronically.

primary_outcome.measure: Embr thermal device usage, average number of minutes per day per participant
primary_outcome.description: Number of minutes logged with the Embr device.

primary_outcome.measure: Embr thermal device usage, average number of sessions per day per participant
primary_outcome.description: Number of sessions logged with the Embr device.

secondary_outcome.measure: Hot Flash Related Daily Interference Scale (HFRDIS), change in score
secondary_outcome.description: The Hot Flash Related Daily Interference Scale is a 10-item self-report measure that assesses the interference on several aspects of functioning associated with hot flashes. This valid and reliable self-report measure is widely used in prostate cancer research. Scores range from 0 to 100, with higher scores indicating greater interference.

secondary_outcome.measure: PROMIS Sleep Disturbance short form 4a, change in score
secondary_outcome.description: The PROMIS Sleep Disturbance SF 4a is a 4-item self report measure of perceived difficulties falling asleep and staying asleep, as well as sleep satisfaction. The 4 items are scored 1-5 where 1 is good quality and 5 is poor quality for a total score range of 4 (good quality) to 20 (poor quality).

secondary_outcome.measure: PROMIS Sleep-Related Impairment short form 8a, change in score
secondary_outcome.description: The PROMIS Sleep-Related Impairment SF 8a is an 8-item self reported measure of perceived alertness, sleepiness, and tiredness during usual waking hours. The 8 items are scored 1-5 where 1 is good quality and 5 is poor quality for a total score range of 8 (good quality) to 40 (poor quality).

secondary_outcome.measure: Epworth sleepiness scale, change in score
secondary_outcome.description: The Epworth Sleepiness Scale is a widely used measure of daytime sleepiness. Scores range from 0 to 24; scores of greater than 10 indicate excessive daytime sleepiness.

other_outcome.description: Self-report 10-question survey of hot flash and night sweat number, duration, interference, bothersome rating, and control of interference. Score range 0 to 86 with higher score indicating greater negative impact of vasomotor symptoms.

other_outcome.measure: Temperature-related quality of life and symptoms, change in score
other_outcome.description: Self-report measure of temperature-related quality of life and symptoms. Scores range from 0 to 100 with higher scores indicating greater quality of life.
Self-report 8-question survey at end of study.

arm_group.description: Use of the Embr thermal device

intervention.description: Participants use the Embr thermal device for 4 weeks

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Have received a diagnosis of prostate cancer and have received treatment with GnRH agonist or antagonist therapy or orchiectomy at least 1 month prior to enrollment.
- May have received prior definitive radiation therapy or surgery (>60 days prior to study).
- Have bothersome hot flashes (occurrence â‰¥ 28 times per week and at least moderately bothersome).
- Presence of hot flashes for >30 days prior to study entry.
- Have a working smartphone (iPhone 6 or greater; or Android 8.0 or greater).
- Willing to downloading and use the Embr thermal device companion app on their phone
- Willing to wear the Embr thermal device for 4 weeks, and charge and sync the device daily
- In order to complete the mandatory patient-completed measures, participants must be able to speak and/or read English
Exclusion Criteria:
- Planned treatment with chemotherapy and/or any medical intervention that will impact hot flashes, sleep, or other daily activities of daily life during the 4-week study.
- History of a known sleep disorder, other than insomnia (eg, obstructive sleep apnea, restless leg syndrome), or medical or psychiatric condition that affects sleep, or undergoing treatment for insomnia.
- History of cognitive impairment or dysfunction.
- Seizure history, history of recurrent falls, or known brain metastases.
- Uncontrolled intercurrent illness.
- Individuals with a second malignancy other than non-melanoma skin cancers.
- Individuals taking psychotropic medications or illicit drugs that may alter cognition, concentration, or behavior.
- Individuals taking prescription sleep medications.
- Individuals who report consuming more than 7 alcoholic beverages/week and/or frequent alcohol consumption within 2 hours prior to bed.

overall_official.affiliation: Northwestern University Feinberg School of Medicine

patient_data.ipd_description: Anonymized dataset of selected variables that underlie results in a publication. Some data may not be amenable to complete anonymization and will not be shared to ensure appropriate confidentiality of participant's data.
